summary: This is a letter from the U.S. Department of Justice Criminal Division to U.S. Attorney Audrey Strauss, authorizing her to apply for a court order to compel a witness to testify or provide information in the Epstein matter, as the witness is refusing on the basis of self-incrimination. It signifies an ongoing investigation where witness cooperation is being compelled.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.context: The recipient of the letter, authorized to apply for a court order to compel a witness to testify in the Epstein matter.

persons.name: Deputy Assistant Attorney General
persons.context: The signatory of the letter, approving the request for authority to compel witness testimony.

events.title: DOJ Authorization for Witness Immunity Request
events.description: The Deputy Assistant Attorney General authorizes U.S. Attorney Audrey Strauss to apply for a court order to compel a witness to testify or provide information in the Epstein matter, as the witness is invoking the privilege against self-incrimination.

locations: 1 St. Andrews Plaza, New York, NY
keyFacts: The U.S. Department of Justice authorized the pursuit of compelled testimony from a witness in the Epstein case on October 12, 2021.
The witness was refusing to testify or provide information based on the privilege against self-incrimination.
The authorization was granted under 18 U.S.C. §§ 6002-6003, which govern immunity for witnesses.
The letter indicates an ongoing investigation or legal proceeding in the Southern District of New York related to the Epstein matter.
